results.title: 1960s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous model miniature celebrates the screen stories Australians loved during the 1960s.

constellations_primary.name: 1960s television
constellations_primary.description: After its debut in the fifties, Australians rapidly became enthusiastic television viewers in the sixties as American imports started to be mixed with notable local productions.

results.description: The 60s might have been the first full decade of Australian television, but there was a surprising lack of it on the small screen as the local industry began to establish itself. In lieu of the necessary infrastructure, shows from the US dominated due to the low-cost of syndication. This all changed with requirements that commercial TV stations begin broadcasting forty per cent Australian content, which led to the first homegrown drama Consider Your Verdict in 1961. The one-hour program ran for 160 episodes on Channel 7 and ushered in a wave of other seminal Aussie shows like Four Corners and Skippy The Bush Kangaroo.
description_for_label: The 60s might have been the first full decade of Australian television, but there was a surprising lack of it on the small screen as the local industry began to establish itself. In lieu of the necessary infrastructure, shows from the US dominated due to the low-cost of syndication. This all changed with requirements that commercial TV stations begin broadcasting forty per cent Australian content, which led to the first homegrown drama Consider Your Verdict in 1961. The one-hour program ran for 160 episodes on Channel 7 and ushered in a wave of other seminal Aussie shows like Four Corners and Skippy The Bush Kangaroo.

results.title: 14 Days to Remember
results.creator_credit: Peter Hood, Bob Whittington and I T N
results.brief_description: A compilation of news footage covering historic events of the past thirty years: 1961 - East Germany builds the Berlin Wall; 1963 - U.S. President Kennedy is assassinated; 1968 - Soviet forces invade Czechoslovakia; 1969 - the first man on the moon; 1974 - the U.S. Watergate scandal; 1975 - the fall of Saigon ending the Vietnam War; 1980 - Iranian Embassy Siege; 1981 - the wedding of Britain’s Prince Charles and Lady Diana; 1982 - Britain invades the Falklands and wins back the islands; 1984 - the IRA attempt to blow up the entire British Cabinet meeting at Brighton; 1984 - Bhopal where poison gas leaks kill more than 3,000 Indians; 1986 - the Shuttle Disaster; 1986 - the Russian nuclear reactor at Chernobyl blows; 1988 - the tragedy of the Armenian earthquake.

holdings.name: VHS; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

After his signature opening title, ‘Round About Alice’, Wallace goes to the desert landscape around Alice Springs, in the Northern Territory, including close-ups of wildflowers and distance shots of ‘Mount Conner’. We see Alice Springs streets and landmarks, and the annual (since 1970) ‘Alice Springs Lions Club Camel Cup’ race. Features the historic Alice Springs Telegraph Station (1872), once also the site of ‘The Bungalow’ school, (1932-1942) for children then identified by government as ‘part aboriginal’. Wallace then films in the dramatic landscape of the ‘McDonnell Ranges’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Wallace Clarke titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Round About Alice’, ‘A W.H.C film’.
00:01:10:00 classic Australian style windmill spinning in wind
00:01:14:00 Mount Conner in distance
00:03:26:00 Street scenes Alice Springs
00:03:47:00 John Flynn Memorial Church, Alice Springs, exterior and interior.
00:04:31:00 extended sequence of camel racing, including scenes of watching crowd, a Scottish pipe band, and particpants in fancy dress
00:07:21:00 night sequence with illumintaed ‘Lions Cup’ sign with outline of a camel in lihghts; fireworks
00:08:02:00 Anzac Hill War Memorial (dedicated 1934) at Alice Springs, followed by aerial views of the town
00:08:32:00 Alice Springs Telegraph Station buildings and surrounds
00:09:15:00 Gravestones in the Alice Springs Telegraph Station Cemetery
00:09:58:00 John Flynn gravesite memorial
00:10:19:00 Roadsign for Simpsons Gap followed by scenes of and in McDonnell Ranges, including camping activities.

results.title: 1950s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature model celebrates the evolving design of rooms we watch TV in and the birth of TV in Australia.

constellations_primary.name: 1950s television
constellations_primary.description: "Good evening ... and welcome to television." Bruce Gyngell’s famous words launched television in Australia in 1956 on Sydney’s TCN9, with the medium finally arriving in the country towards the later end of the decade.

results.description: “Good evening … and welcome to television.” Those were the famous words of television pioneer Bruce Gyngell that first launched television in Australia in 1956 on Sydney’s TCN9. Experimental transmissions had been taking place as early as 1929. Yet the delay in broadcasting came from heated public debate over what kind of television the nation would have: government-run, like Britain, or commercial, like the US. The result was a uniquely combined service, utilising elements of both. The medium reached the masses just in time for the Melbourne Summer Olympic Games in September.
description_for_label: “Good evening … and welcome to television.” Those were the famous words of television pioneer Bruce Gyngell that first launched television in Australia in 1956 on Sydney’s TCN9. Experimental transmissions had been taking place as early as 1929. Yet the delay in broadcasting came from heated public debate over what kind of television the nation would have: government-run, like Britain, or commercial, like the US. The result was a uniquely combined service, utilising elements of both. The medium reached the masses just in time for the Melbourne Summer Olympic Games in September.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is made up of two films. The first captures the dramatic coastline of the ‘Shipwreck Coast’ in the west of Victoria. It also features the ‘Fletcher Jones’ (clothing manufacturers) at Warrnambool including the ‘Silver Ball’ water tower designed by Ralph Jones, engineer and eldest son of owner David Fletcher Jones. Erected in 1967 as part of the Pleasant Hill factory’s extensive fire protection system, the water tower was state heritage listed, along with other aspects of the Pleasant Hill site, in August 2006.

The second film features Victorian National parks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title ‘Coastal Panarama’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:23:00 roadsign ‘Port Campbell National Park’ followed by views from the ocean cliffs including the Twelve Apostles
00:01:52:00 an old grave with an engraved headstone for members of the Carmichael family followed by dramatic views out over the roiling sea
00:05:46:00 the Fletcher Jones headquarters building in Warrnambool, Victoria
00:05:49:00 the ‘hawkers wagon’ emblazoned with information on history of Fletcher Jones as ‘painstaking tailors’
00:05:55:00 views around the grounds of the Fletcher Jones headquarters
00:06:45:00 old boats and sailing ships in dry dock possibly at Flagstaff Hill maritime museum, Warrnambool
00:07:40:00 the Lady Bay lighthouse at Flastaff Hill in Warrnambool and views of a canon looking out to sea
00:09:17:00 a distinctive rocky outcrop on a beach
00:09:52:00 looking out over the waterways and beaches of Warrnambool from a higher vantage point followed by some caves and grassy paddocks with grazing sheep
00:10:29:00 title card ‘The End’
00:10:50:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’ and ‘National Parks of the S.E.’
00:11:15:00 roadsign ‘Mount Richmond National Park’ follwed by close-ups of wildflowers
00:12:03:00 a car with gear packed on the roofrack
00:12:14:00 sign ‘Discovery Bay Coastal Park National Parks Service’
00:14:40:00 bee-keeping
00:14:49:00 walking up a steep sand dune and down again; views of the dunes and beach; pelicans on the water; views of the sea and beaches
00:15:49:00 fishing and a child runs across the frame in ‘gumboots’
00:15:55:00 sign ‘Lower Glenelg National Park’ and ‘Glenelg River’, a large river or lagoon, wildflowers and sea birds
00:17:08:00 sunset over the sea
00:18:57:00 boathouses and small boats on old jettys
00:19:07:00 sign ‘State Border South Australia’
00:19:35:00 jetty and motor boat
00:19:57:00 farmland with old buildings and a windmill
00:21:01:00 looking out from the rocky shore
00:21:30:00 old entry signs ‘Clarke Park’ followed by ‘Dingley Dell’ which is the historic home of one of Australia’s most famous poets, Adam Lindsay Gordon, and views of the cottage in which he lived

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Papua New Guinea May - June 1961; No.1’, shows landscapes, seascapes, vegetation, people, villages, boats, roads, cars and other infrastructure of Papua New Guinea. It includes aerial footage of sea, forest, and mountains, and scenes of the (former) Royal Australian Navy base HMAS Tarangau at Manus Island.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:20:00 activities at a small airport
00:00:43:00 ‘Trans Australian Airlines’ (TAA) seaplane
00:02:12:00 luggage being manually loaded onto Ansett Australia plane by local staff.
00:02:36:00 passengers file past local staff wearing distinctive ‘Anset AAA’ waist-to-calf tunics
00:03:21:00 brief glimpses of a rugby match
00:07:47:00 outdoor classroom with young students at work
00:10:27:00 group of men constructing (or repairing) a traditional village building
00:14:04:00 woman preparing coconut with a large knife
00:16:53:00 large ship (probably one of the Royal Australian Navy) in port
00:17:06:00 small monument bearing sign ‘Tarangau’ (Royal Australlian Navy base HMAS Tarangau, commissioned 1950)
00:17:26:00 sailors in white uniform lined-up on deck
00:17:37:00 ship moves off from port
00:20:52:00 a food market with many people
00:27:39:00 distinctive three-sailed boat

It includes aerial footage of sea, forest, and mountains, and scenes of the (former) Royal Australian Navy base HMAS Tarangau at Manus Island.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:20:00 activities at a small airport
00:00:43:00 ‘Trans Australian Airlines’ (TAA) seaplane
00:02:12:00 luggage being manually loaded onto Ansett Australia plane by local staff.
00:02:36:00 passengers file past local staff wearing distinctive ‘Anset AAA’ waist-to-calf tunics
00:03:21:00 brief glimpses of a rugby match
00:07:47:00 outdoor classroom with young students at work
00:10:27:00 group of men constructing (or repairing) a traditional village building
00:14:04:00 woman preparing coconut with a large knife
00:16:53:00 large ship (probably one of the Royal Australian Navy) in port
00:17:06:00 small monument bearing sign ‘Tarangau’ (Royal Australlian Navy base HMAS Tarangau, commissioned 1950)
00:17:26:00 sailors in white uniform lined-up on deck
00:17:37:00 ship moves off from port
00:20:52:00 a food market with many people
00:27:39:00 distinctive three-sailed boat
description_for_label:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Papua New Guinea May - June 1961; No.1’, shows landscapes, seascapes, vegetation, people, villages, boats, roads, cars and other infrastructure of Papua New Guinea. It includes aerial footage of sea, forest, and mountains, and scenes of the (former) Royal Australian Navy base HMAS Tarangau at Manus Island.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:20:00 activities at a small airport
00:00:43:00 ‘Trans Australian Airlines’ (TAA) seaplane
00:02:12:00 luggage being manually loaded onto Ansett Australia plane by local staff.
00:02:36:00 passengers file past local staff wearing distinctive ‘Anset AAA’ waist-to-calf tunics
00:03:21:00 brief glimpses of a rugby match
00:07:47:00 outdoor classroom with young students at work
00:10:27:00 group of men constructing (or repairing) a traditional village building
00:14:04:00 woman preparing coconut with a large knife
00:16:53:00 large ship (probably one of the Royal Australian Navy) in port
00:17:06:00 small monument bearing sign ‘Tarangau’ (Royal Australlian Navy base HMAS Tarangau, commissioned 1950)

00:17:37:00 ship moves off from port
00:20:52:00 a food market with many people

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows scenes from around the Northern Territory as Wallace and companions travel by car, with what appears to be camping gear packed on the roof, to Kulera, Finke River and Tempe Downs. As always, Wallace films the various landscapes as he travels.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 road sign ‘Kulgera 168’ followed by views of the long dusty red road ahead from the moving car and a handmade sign for ‘Goody Lookout’
00:00:30:00 sign ‘Finke River’, the river and a low bridge which the travellers’ car crosses
00:01:05:00 metalwork sign for ‘NTRB Henbury Meteorites Reserve’ followed by driving scenes through dusty scrub
00:03:14:00 a hopping kangaroo and a Northern Territory magpie goose walks through long grasses
00:03:35:00 old cattleyards
00:03:45:00 Kings Canyon and many views of surrounding countryside
00:09:46:00 a golden full moon at night

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film shows a trip to Wilson’s Promontory, Victoria including the beach at Tidal River and a group of people hiking around the prom.

Originally made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:38:00 a banksia tree
00:01:02:00 group of people walking onto a beach with large boulders
00:01:37:00 taking photos on the shoreline
00:02:35:00 woman sketching
00:05:49:00 a little lizard
00:06:27:00 group of people hiking
00:07:43:00 man sitting on a rock looking over a view
00:08:05:00 group of people watching the view
00:09:56:00 the river going into the sea
00:12:23:00 the footbridge at Tidal River
00:14:12:00 a rosella on a branch and feeding from someone’s hand

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group trip by tourist bus, four wheel drive vehicles and truck around the ‘Gulf Country’. The Gulf Country is the region of woodland and savanna grassland surrounding the Gulf of Carpentaria in north western Queensland and parts of the Northern Territory, Australia.

We see many dirt roads and sandy tracks so that we see both a tourist bus and four wheel drive vehicles being dug out of the sand. As always, Wallace includes close-ups of any flora and fauna that catch
his eye along the way.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Gulf Country’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:15:00 sign for ‘Four Wheel Drive’.
00:01:21:00 a large lorry style truck travelling ahead on dirt road.
00:01:31:00 digging a vehicle out of sand on a track.
00:02:30:00 tourist bus being hauled from the sandy track by a truck.
00:03:42:00 particularly colourful bird in a tree.
00:03:57:00 people in a small boat catching fish.
00:04:55:00 a row of tents for camping lined up along a riverbank.
00:07:45:00 close up of a blackened ‘billy can’ set over a fire and then a wider shot of a group of picnic-goers.
00:08:09:00 a woman in an example of a 1970s style ‘halter-neck’ top.
00:08:32:00 animal footprints in the dust followed by a large snake making progress through the grass
00:09:14:00 large truck and bus with baggage loaded on roof travel down a dusty road
00:09:57:00 cattle in stockyards
00:10:27:00 wetlands and wildflowers
00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Wallace Clarke Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm film. Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.
